Verification through official sources: The experts consulted the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, which provided information from the National Vital Statistics System (NVSS), a reliable collection of public health data overseen by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
Analysis of statistical data: The experts examined the 2007 NVSS report, which showed that the death rate for individuals with less than a high school diploma was 529.5 per 100,000, or 2.7 times higher than the rate for those with at least some college education. This statistical analysis supported the claim made by the Surgeon General.
Expert consultation and consensus: PolitiFact Georgia consulted with various experts and read studies on the subject. These experts agreed that there is a strong link between education and health, supporting the claim made by the Surgeon General.
Historical research and evidence: The experts mentioned that researchers have been aware of the close relationship between education and health since the 1970s. They also referred to a 2008 study that showed better-educated individuals, particularly black men, tend to live longer than their less-educated counterparts. This historical research and evidence further supported the authenticity of the claim.
